title: Common painkillers linked to one of the world's biggest health threats
text:
A common household staple has been linked to one of the ﻿world's biggest health threats: antibiotic resistance.

The World Health Organisation (WHO) reported that bacterial resistance was directly responsible for 1.27 million global deaths in 2019 and called it a significant global threat to public health.

Now ﻿research from ﻿the University of South Australia has revealed common painkillers such as ﻿﻿ibuprofen and paracetamol have been fuelling antibiotic resistance.

READ MORE: Dangerous inmate only cell contact for mushroom killer

Common painkillers like ﻿﻿ibuprofen and paracetamol have been fuelling antibiotic resistance. (Getty)

The first-of-its-kind study found the two drugs drove resistance when used ﻿individually and could even amplify it when used together.

In one instance, researchers discovered that using ﻿ibuprofen and paracetamol alongside the broad-spectrum antibiotic ciprofloxacin to treat Escherichia coli (E. coli) led to significantly increased bacterial mutations.

That made ﻿the E. coli highly resistant to the antibiotic.

"Worryingly, the bacteria were not only resistant to the antibiotic ciprofloxacin, but increased resistance was also observed to multiple other antibiotics from different classes," lead researcher Associate Professor Rietie Venter said.

"We also uncovered the genetic mechanisms behind this resistance, with ibuprofen and paracetamol both activating the bacteria's defences to expel antibiotics and render them less effective."

READ MORE: Australia Post suspends deliveries to the US after Trump tariffs

Where Australia ranks in countries with the greatest health freedoms View Gallery

Researchers also assessed the effects of several other medications﻿ on antibiotic resistance, including metformin ﻿and pseudoephedrine.

The results made it clear that ﻿"antibiotic resistance isn't just about antibiotics anymore".

"Antibiotics have long been vital in treating infectious diseases, but their widespread overuse and misuse have driven a global rise in antibiotic-resistant bacteria," Venter ﻿said.

The study suggested further studies into the impacts of other drugs on ﻿antibiotic effectiveness were required in order to better understand and tackle the issue.

Venter said "antibiotic resistance isn't just about antibiotics anymore". (Getty)

This was increasingly important﻿ for ﻿vulnerable groups, such as people in aged care homes where many residents took multiple medications daily.

"This doesn't mean we should stop using these medications, but we do need to be more mindful about how they interact with antibiotics – and that includes looking beyond just two-drug combinations."

title: Profits at Andrew Forrest's mining giant Fortescue slide by 41 per cent
text:
A﻿ustralian mining giant Fortescue today announced a 41 per cent drop in its annual profit after a year of falling iron ore prices.

The mining and green energy company run by Australian billionaire Andrew Forrest recorded a net profit after tax of $US3.37 billion ($5.2 billion), compared with $US5.68 billion a year ago.

The figure came in slightly below market forecasts.﻿

READ MORE: Australia Post suspends deliveries to the US after Trump tariffs

Andrew Forrest, executive chairman and founder of Fortescue. (The Sydney Morning Herald)

Shareholders will get a 60-cent final dividend next month, bringing the complete year total to $1.10 per share.

Shaky global iron ore prices, and falling demand from China's factories and construction sector were behind the profit dip.

Executive chairman Forrest﻿, an advocate for green hydrogen as a clean energy source, today acknowledged transforming his company into a major producer of the energy-rich fuel was challenging.

"No new industry or transformational shift has ever been linear or easy," Forrest said in a statement to the ASX today.

"We haven't always got it right, but we learn every day from advances and setbacks."﻿

In July, Fortescue announced it was cutting 700 jobs across its global operations amid reports it was scaling back its goals to be a major hydrogen producer.

Falling demand for iron ore in Chinese factories has impacted global prices of the commodity. (AP)

But﻿ the company insisted its green energy and zero emissions pushes will continue.

"Fortescue remains resolute in its commitment to be the world's leading green technology, energy and metals company with a laser focus on achieving Real Zero by 2030," it said in a statement.

Fortescue ﻿was founded in Western Australia in 2003 and exports more than 190 million tonnes of iron ore each year.

title: President said just the right thing to get on Trump's good side
text:
President Donald Trump took to social media before meeting with South Korean President Lee Jae Myung to threaten not to do business with Seoul because of a “Purge or Revolution” that he claimed was taking place in the country.

But any prospect of a hostile Oval Office meeting evaporated after Lee heaped praise onto the US president — lauding the decor, beseeching Trump to continue to help with Korean peace efforts and even suggesting a Trump Tower in North Korea.

“We've known each other and gotten along very well,” Trump said, before adding: “It's a great honour to be with you and congratulations on your election. That was a big one, and we're with you 100 per cent.”

The Oval Office has been decked out with gold decor in Donald Trump's second term. (AP)

The cordial display showed how world leaders are taking notes from previous meetings between Trump and heads of state, who've largely chosen the route of praise and adulation rather than confrontation as they seek favourable trade terms and continued military aid from Washington.

It was one of the first big foreign policy tests for Lee, who took over a country in a state of political turmoil since its former leader, Yoon Suk Yeol, was ousted from office after imposing martial law .

Lee, elected in June, began by praising one of Trump's pet projects: presidential interior design.

“I heard that you recently redecorated the Oval Office, and I would like to say that it looks very bright and beautiful,” Lee said through an interpreter. “It has the dignity of America, and it symbolises the new future and prosperity of America.”

He noted that the Dow Jones index has reached record highs (although Lee made sure to add the caveat that “it went down a bit”) and asked Trump, who has been on a mission to receive the Nobel Peace Prize, to reunify the two Koreas and even perhaps see the construction of a Trump Tower in North Korea accompanied by a round of golf.



Lee also agreed with Trump's assertion that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un would not have continued to enhance his nuclear capabilities the last few years had Trump remained in office.

Noting a “renaissance” that is taking place, Lee said, “I believe you are the only leader who has made such accomplishments.”

What happened in South Korea

The tone was a far cry from Trump's confrontational social media post earlier on Monday.

He later elaborated that he was referring to raids on churches and on a US military base by the new South Korean government, which they “probably shouldn't have done."

“I heard bad things,” Trump told reporters in the Oval Office on Monday morning. “I don't know if it's true or not. I'll be finding out.”

Trump did not identify specific raids. But earlier this month, South Korean police raided a church led by a conservative activist pastor who authorities allege is connected to a riot by Yoon’s supporters at a Seoul court in January, after it issued an arrest warrant for him.

A special prosecutor’s team that is investigating corruption allegations against Yoon’s arrested wife, former first lady Kim Keon Hee, also raided the facilities of the Unification Church over allegations that one of its officials gave her luxury goods.

South Korean President Lee Jae Myung meets with Donald Trump in the Oval Office. (AP)

Meanwhile, Osan Air Base, which is jointly operated by the United States and South Korea, was also the target of a raid last month by investigators looking into how Yoon’s activation of martial law transpired. South Korean investigators stressed the search was limited to areas controlled by Seoul and did not involve US military operations.

Asked about his assertions by a reporter in front of Lee, Trump declined to confront the South Korean president and instead said the two will discuss it later.

“It didn't sound to me like South Korea,” Trump said.

Lee explained that the special prosecutor was tapped by the country's National Assembly to investigate the actions of Yoon, who Lee said staged a “self-coup.”

At that point, Trump interjected, “Is his name Deranged Jack Smith, by any chance?” He was referring to the special prosecutor who led two criminal cases against Trump before the Republican president was reelected to a second term.

Yoon, who was elected to a five-year term in 2022, was considered more ideologically aligned with Trump and had even taken up golfing again after the U.S. president was reelected last November to try to forge a bond with him.

Lee led the South Korean parliament's efforts to overturn Yoon's martial law decree while impeaching him. The nation's Constitutional Court formally dismissed Yoon in April.

The new president

Elected in June, Lee was a former child laborer with an arm deformity who rose his way through South Korea’s political ranks to lead the liberal Democratic Party and win the presidency after multiple attempts.

At a subsequent remarks in Washington on Monday night, Lee suggested that Trump's post had been “threatening” and said it had him worried he might face a “Zelenksyy moment" — similar to when Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was hounded out of the Oval Office by Trump and Vice President JD Vance following a contentious meeting in February.

But Lee also said the South Korean-US relationship was strong enough that he was confident Trump wouldn't work to undermine it. Instead, he said the pair had “very good conversations” that went “beyond my expectations" and took longer than originally scheduled.

“Everybody gave me the advice to have patience,” Lee said of his meeting with Trump.

He said he also told Trump that South Korea would increase its defence spending, even as it works to ease tensions between his country and North Korea.

South Korean troops march during a celebration to mark the 75th anniversary of Armed Forces Day. (AP)

“We will increase our defence budget, which will be used to transform the Korean military into a smart military that will prevail in future,” Lee said.

Lee said he and Trump also discussed modernising their countries' trade relations, which follows a July deal that has Seoul investing hundreds of billions of dollars in the U.S. That agreement set tariffs on South Korean goods at 15 per cent after Trump threatened rates as high as 25 per cent.

Seoul has one of the largest trade surpluses among Washington’s NATO and Indo-Pacific allies, and countries where the US holds a trade deficit has drawn particular ire from Trump, who wants to eliminate such trade imbalances.

Trump also said Monday that he’d like to scrap the US lease with South Korea that covers Osan Air Base and instead get ownership of the land.

READ MORE: Australia Post suspends deliveries to the US after Trump tariffs

title: Major pig-to-human organ transplant milestone marks world first
text:
A genetically modified pig lung has functioned in a human recipient for nine days in a major world first.

Research published in Nature Medicine may﻿ represent the first documented instance of cross-species lung transplants, the authors said.

In previous, similar studies, organs such as kidneys, livers, and hearts from gene-edited pigs have been feasibly transplanted into humans.

READ MORE: Dangerous inmate only cell contact for mushroom killer

A lung from a gene-edited pig has been transplanted into a human. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

However, lung transplantation brought new challenges due to the complexity of the organ.

﻿The research team, from China's National Clinical Research Centre for Respiratory Disease, transplanted the left lung of a gene-edited pig into a 39-year-old human recipient.

The recipient had previously been declared brain dead in four clinical assessments.﻿

READ MORE: Australia Post suspends deliveries to the US after Trump tariffs

The pig had undergone gene editing to remove the antigens that could otherwise activate the human immune system and prompt a rejection.

The study authors found the lung was accepted, and maintained "viability and functionality" for nine days.

However, the researchers did observe signs of lung damage at 24 hours after the transplant, and signs of antibody-mediated rejection of the organ on day three and day six.

Kidnapped woman emerges after 18 years View Gallery

They terminated the experiment on day nine.

"The findings represent a first step for pig-to-human lung transplantation," the authors said in a release.

"However, improvements are needed to optimise both the genetic modifications made in the donor pig and the immunosuppressive drugs needed to avoid immune-mediated rejection of the lung and to maintain long-term function."

title: New plan to help stop tradies being lured away from apprenticeships
text:
The federal government hopes a new cash payment program will help apprentices finish their qualifications rather than being lured away by high-paid unskilled jobs.

The initiative comes after an increase ﻿in young tradies leaving their apprenticeships for higher-paying jobs, crushing efforts to boost the national construction workforce amidst the current skill shortage and housing crisis.

"We need 40 trades to build a home, and we know every single trade is in shortage," Master Builders Australia chief executive Denita Wawn said.

The initiative comes after an increase ﻿in young tradies leaving their apprenticeships for higher-paying jobs. (9News)

Last year, 24,335 young Australians completed a construction apprenticeship, but, 30,470 withdrew or abandoned their apprenticeship before finishing.

The government's new program hopes to curb this trend, offering ﻿$10,000 in payments, delivered in $2000 installments on top of wages for apprentices.

Australia is gripped by a twin crisis: a skills shortage that's making it harder to fix the housing shortage. (AP)

Since July, 1291 construction apprentices have been approved for the program, with carpenters, electricians, and plumbers making up most of the approvals, and Victoria leading the way.

"These incentives are just part of the ways in which we'll encourage more people to start apprenticeships and be supported to finish them," Minister for Skills and Training, Andrew Giles said.

title: One of Australia's biggest banks will soon ask customers for a selfie
text:
Exclusive: O﻿ne of Australia's biggest banks will soon be asking all new customers to take a selfie to confirm their identity.

N﻿ational Australia Bank (NAB) will start using selfies to help combat the spread of identity theft from next month.

The bank said the new feature will be a breakthrough in the fight against cybercriminals.

NAB will start asking new customers to verify their identity with a selfie. (9News)

NAB said new customers will verify their identity using their biometric data, also known as full facial recognition.

It's designed to stop stolen licences and passports being used to open dummy bank accounts, which is a fast-moving problem in the world of scams.

"Over 255,000 Australians a year have their identity stolen or compromised," Head of NAB group investigations Chris Sheehan told 9News Finance Editor Chris Kohler.

﻿"Now that number, I suspect, is on the low side.

"We're confident we're going to make a real difference."﻿

READ MORE: A warmer and wetter spring in store for much of Australia

The bank said its their latest move to target scammers who steal identities. (Getty)

Industry analysts support the move, but say with more data actually comes more exposure.

"What we need to worry about is where is this information being held," technology expert Trevor Long said.

﻿"This is the last thing we want, our names, our details and photos of ourselves being hacked."

NAB said there are no plans to make existing customers verify in this way and that anyone concerned should visit a branch in person to open a new account.

The move comes as the ACCC reports scam losses are increasing, with $175 million lost in just the first half of this year alone.﻿

title: Four men charged over alleged AFL Brownlow Medal betting scheme
text:
Four men have been charged with a range of offences linked to alleged suspicious gambling on the AFL's Brownlow Medal awards in 2021 and 2022.

It comes as part of a protracted investigation by Victoria Police's Sporting Integrity Intelligence Unit, with the initial arrests of four men occurring in 2022.

It is not clear whether the four men arrested in 2022 are any of the same men charged this week.

The 2021 Brownlow Medal was won by Port Adelaide's Ollie Wines, while the 2022 award was won by Carlton's Patrick Cripps.

A 34-year-old Glenroy man, a 32-year-old Doreen man, a 31-year-old Hadfield man and a 35-year-old Reservoir man have been charged over the allegations.

At the time of the arrests, police alleged a person with knowledge of the voting tally of certain AFL matches distributed the information to a group of people.

In the case of the Reservoir man, police allege he used corrupt conduct information for betting purposes on 34 occasions and faces 53 separate charges connected to wagering on the 2021 and 2022 Brownlow Medal awards.

The maximum penalty for the offences is 10 years in jail.

AFL chief executive Andrew Dillon, then-general manager of football operations, said at the time of the 2022 arrests that there was no "information to suggest that the outcome of the Brownlow Medal was impacted", as the allegations related to the leaking of results after matches.

The AFL said in 2022 that there was no evidence the outcome of either the 2021 or 2022 awards were affected by the alleged betting. (AAP: Joe Castro)

The four men are scheduled to appear at Melbourne Magistrates' Court on September 11.

In a statement, the AFL acknowledged the charges laid by Victoria Police in connection with the 2021 and 2022 awards.

"As the matter is before the courts, the AFL is not in a position to provide any further comments," an AFL spokesperson said.

title: Gold Coast Titans need new 'identity' to win fans, says incoming coach
text:
The Gold Coast Titans' incoming head coach says the embattled NRL club needs to build a distinctive identity as it looks to recover from a dismal season.

Josh Hannay will replace Des Hasler next season — a year before Hasler's contract was due to end and three months after Titans' owner Rebecca Frizelle said: "We want him here until the end of 2026."

It also comes just two years after Justin Holbrook was sacked as head coach.

Hannay said he recognised the "enormous challenge" in front of him.

"The best teams in this competition have a clearly identifiable style of play — it's there for everybody to see when they take the field," Hannay said.

" I want to develop an identity for the club that resonates with the people of the Gold Coast and all the fans that support the Titans. "

Hannay has been the Cronulla Sharks' assistant coach, under Craig Fitzgibbon, since 2021.

He has also worked as assistant to Billy Slater's Queensland Origin side, winning three of the past four titles.

No 'rose-coloured glasses'

The Titans sit at the bottom of the NRL ladder, losing their past four games and winning just five this season.

Hannay, like his predecessor, will seek to reverse what has been an ongoing struggle for the Titans to perform at finals level.

They finished 14th in 2024 and in 2023, a long way from 2010's preliminary final.

Hannay said he was not coming to the role with "rose-coloured glasses on".

Titans coach Des Hasler coached Manly Sea Eagles to their 2013 grand final win. (AAP: Dave Hunt)

"There's an opportunity there to do something that's just not been achieved before by the club, which is A: go to a grand final and B: win a competition," he said.

" Where the club sits currently, that naturally looks a long way away. "

Hannay said the Titans should look to the Maroons to build a distinctive style of play.

"[Queensland] have been synonymous for the way they play, the grit they play with — very identifiable traits," Hannay said.

"That's something that started in 1980, and it's still there today."

Recruitment decisions

Former Penrith player Scott Sattler will return to the club as its new director of football — the second time he has held the senior administrative role.

"We have to put a team together, not only on the field but off the field, that knows what success looks like," Sattler said.

" In rugby league, there's one currency that we talk in and that is winning — a lot of the time, fans won't accept anything less. "

But he said some previous recruitment decisions had been "astute" while others "have probably left the club in a hole, especially from a salary-cap point of view".

The Titans lost to the Panthers here in round 22, earlier in August. (Getty Images: Chris Hyde)

"[This] doesn't give you the ability to go to market and negotiate with certain players," Sattler said.

"But also it's about the people that are around the club and whether they've been involved in the modern game."

Hannay said the Titans had a "rich nursery" of young players.

"There's a lot of untapped talent underneath that no-one's yet seen."

Hannay will begin his three-year contract with the Titans after he ends the 2025 season with the Sharks.

title: Grazier who trained in town pool completes third huge open water swim
text:
A Los Angeles beach is about as big a change in scenery from far west New South Wales as you can get.

It was here on the Southern Californian coastline that outback grazier Brendan Cullen completed his latest sporting feat — swimming the 32.3-kilometre Catalina Channel from Santa Cantaline Island to the US mainland.

"It was bloody good to get it done," Mr Cullen said.

The majority of the more than 13-hour swim was completed in the dark to avoid the channel's blustery afternoon winds, in conditions the 52-year-old described as "magnificent", with little wind and water temperatures of around 22 degrees Celsius.

"One of the things that I'll never forget was the bioluminescence in the water, " he told ABC Broken Hill.

A victorious Brendan Cullen celebrates from the beach in LA. (Supplied: Brendan Cullen)

"Every time your hand hit the water, it would just flash like a rainbow. It was unbelievable.

"And every now and again you could see the bottom of the ocean just flicker, and it was like the stars underneath."

Becoming a Triple Crown threat

In the lead-up to the swim, Mr Cullen, who runs Kars Station, more than 1,000 kilometres west of Sydney, had been training at Menindee Lakes and Broken Hill pool.

Although noticeably devoid of waves, both were sufficient for preparing Mr Cullen for swimming the English Channel twice before taking on the Catalina Channel, in his bid to conquer the Triple Crown of Open Water Swimming.

The grazier first completed the 33-kilometre English Channel solo in 2022, before taking it on again a year later as part of a relay.

Brendan Cullen (right) and a friend wade out of the Menindee Lake's Lake Speculation after a chilly early-morning swim. (ABC Broken Hill: Bill Ormonde)

Although the US and English channels were of a similar length, Mr Cullen said his English Channel swims were far more challenging than the Catalina Channel due to the water temperature, with the UK swim taking him four hours longer.

Even at night, the US waters were significantly warmer than the freezing stretch of water between England and France.

Mentor and mate's 'sacrifice'

Mr Cullen had entered the water at Santa Cantaline Island with his friend, coach and mentor Mike Gregory, but his tandem partner made the selfless decision to opt out of the swim when it became obvious the more experienced swimmer was outpacing the grazier.

"He was getting in front of me and then dropping behind me and he was cooling down, and he wasn't quite sure whether he was going to be able to maintain that," Mr Cullen said.

"So, he opted to get out and basically sacrificed his swim for mine.

"Which is a hell of a thing to do."

Left to swim solo, Mr Cullen was supported by his wife, Jacinta, and two daughters, Emma and Charli, who accompanied him in a boat.

Brendan Cullen with Mike Gregory (left), his wife Jacinta and daughters Emma and Charli. (Supplied: Brendan Cullen)

Mr Gregory joined Mr Cullen's family in the boat to cheer him on.

Pushing through discomfort and fatigue as the swim went on, Mr Cullen was jubilant when he made it to shore in LA.

"My shoulders took a bit of a belting," he said.

" Probably the last three hours my shoulder packed it in, so I had to change up my swimming stroke. "

But he was determined not to quit, and recalled thinking: "There's no way in hell I'm getting out."

Not just about swimming

Mr Cullen has been a champion for mental health awareness — he has battled his own illness in the past and is an advocate across western NSW.

So the grazier thought it would be good to raise awareness and money for not-for-profit Find Ya Feet, which runs workshops in schools and sporting clubs about vulnerability.

"School's a tough place to be, especially if you don't want to be there … and [so I] figured it would be an awesome thing to do to raise a few bucks," Mr Cullen said.

Find Ya Feet's founder and chief executive, Tom Herschell, said it was Mr Cullen who first reached out because he wanted to help.

"Anyone who swims out in the Menindee Lakes in the middle of winter when it's as cold as a mother-in-law's kiss has got plenty of front, which I bloody love," Mr Herschell said.

"[He's] just a beautiful man with a beautiful heart and has a vision, and he's a doer."

title: Musk's AI startup xAI sues Apple and ChatGPT maker
text:
Billionaire Elon Musk's artificial intelligence startup xAI has sued Apple and ChatGPT maker OpenAI, accusing them of illegally conspiring to thwart competition for artificial intelligence.

Apple and OpenAI have "locked up markets to maintain their monopolies and prevent innovators like X and xAI from competing," the lawsuit filed in a US federal court on Monday, local time, said.

Apple has partnered with OpenAI to integrate ChatGPT into its operating system for iPhones, iPads, and Macs.

"If not for its exclusive deal with OpenAI, Apple would have no reason to refrain from more prominently featuring the X app and the Grok app in its App Store," the lawsuit said.

In the lawsuit, xAI says it is seeking billions of dollars in alleged damages.

Google to target Aussie kids under 13 with its AI chatbot Gemini Photo shows Gemini AI logo is seen on a phone, held over a laptop Google will launch its Gemini AI chatbot for Australian children under 13 within months, the ABC can reveal.

"This latest filing is consistent with Mr. Musk's ongoing pattern of harassment," an OpenAI spokesperson said in a statement.

Apple did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Later on Monday, Mr Musk posted on his social media platform, X, echoing the allegations in the lawsuit: "A million reviews with 4.9 average for @Grok and still Apple refuses to mention Grok on any lists."

Mr Musk had threatened to sue the California-based Apple earlier this month, writing on X that Apple's behaviour "makes it impossible for any AI company besides OpenAI to reach #1 in the App Store".

OpenAI's ChatGPT became the fastest-growing consumer application. (Reuters: SOPA Images/SI/Rafael Henrique)

OpenAI's ChatGPT became the fastest-growing consumer application in history in the months following its launch in late 2022.

Mr Musk's xAI acquired X in March for $US33 billion ($51 billion) to enhance its chatbot training capabilities.

Mr Musk has also integrated the Grok chatbot into vehicles made by his electric automobile company, Tesla.

xAI was launched less than two years ago and competes with Microsoft-backed OpenAI as well as with Chinese startup DeepSeek.

Antitrust legal experts who are not involved in the lawsuit have said Apple's dominant position in the smartphone market could bolster xAI's claims that the company is illegally tying its iPhone sales with OpenAI's ChatGPT.

On its first birthday, here's what ChatGPT has taught us about artificial intelligence Photo shows A yellow robot sits at a table in front of a birthday cake with a cluster of lit candles in the middle Love it or hate it, OpenAI's ChatGPT has been around for a year and artificial intelligence is becoming more integrated into everyday life.

But they said Apple could counter that its partnership with OpenAI was a business decision in a competitive environment, and that it had no obligation to help its rivals gain market share.

More broadly, the lawsuit could give courts in the United States their first opportunity to assess whether there is a defined market for AI and what it encompasses, a threshold issue in antitrust litigation.

"It's a canary in the coal mine in terms of how courts will treat AI, and treat antitrust and AI," said Christine Bartholomew, a professor at the University at Buffalo School of Law.

Mr Musk is separately suing OpenAI and its CEO, Sam Altman, in federal court in California to stop its conversion from a nonprofit to a for-profit business. Mr Musk co-founded OpenAI with Mr Altman in 2015 as a nonprofit.

Apple's App Store practices have been the focus of multiple lawsuits.

In one ongoing case by Fortnite video game maker Epic Games, a judge ordered Apple to allow greater competition for app payment options.

Reuters

title: Daughter's plea after young, fit dad loses prostate cancer battle
text:
Steven Jones was a fit and healthy 52-year-old when he was given an unexpected cancer diagnosis.

The footy-mad, car-loving Melbourne father of four was diagnosed with aggressive stage-four prostate cancer after a routine check-up with his doctor.

"It was really hard. Your dad is the strongest person in your life and they're always the one helping you and the one that you turn to," daughter Madeline Jones said.

"Then suddenly that flips and you're looking after them and you're caring for them."

Madeline Jones was by her dad's side through the highs and lows of his six-year ordeal. (Supplied: Madeline Jones)

During his final months, Ms Jones moved from her home in Emerald in central Queensland to care for her dad with her three older brothers in Victoria.

The cancer eventually spread to his bones and then brain and Mr Jones's battle against the dreaded disease ended in July, surrounded by his family.

He was 58.

Steven Jones loved the Sydney Swans AFL club and motorsport Formula 1. (Supplied: Madeline Jones)

Ms Jones said the six-year ordeal was an emotionally distressing time for her family.

She now wants to challenge the myth that prostate cancer is an "old man's disease" and highlight its growing national impact as Australia's most commonly diagnosed cancer for males.

"Dad was only in his 50s, he wasn't an elderly man," she said.

"It was heartbreaking but he was surrounded by love and care until the end."

The Jones family (from left): Anthony, Madeline, Steven, Andrew and Matthew. (Supplied: Madeline Jones)

Family's journey

More than 26,000 Australian men are diagnosed with prostate cancer each year and nearly 4,000 will die from the disease.

One in five men are likely to be diagnosed in their lifetime while those with a family history have a higher chance of developing prostate cancer.

Mr Jones had no family history.

From the moment a friend urged Mr Jones to get a PSA (Prostate-Specific Antigen) test, to his final days in palliative care, Ms Jones said his humour and kindness never left him.

A PSA test is a blood test used primarily to screen for prostate cancer.

Madeline Jones says prostate cancer is not an old person's disease after her dad's diagnosis at 52. (Supplied: Madeline Jones)

"The hardest part was watching what he had to go through and the changes in his body throughout the different treatments," she said.

"He didn't recognise himself anymore and I guess he just wanted life to go back to normal, so it was quite tough."

Raising awareness and hope

September is Prostate Cancer Awareness Month, a timely reminder to have important conversations about men's health.

Ms Jones said she was determined to raise awareness in honour of her dad to prevent other families from facing the heartbreak they had endured.

"I really didn't know anything about prostate cancer before Dad got diagnosed so I was learning about it as he was," she said.

"Your partners, dads, uncles, any men in your life, encourage them to get tested."

According to Prostate Cancer Foundation of Australia (PCFA), regional men in Australia have a 24 per cent higher risk of death compared to their urban counterparts due to geographic location and lack of access to health care.

Anne Savage says men with a family history have a higher chance of developing prostate cancer. (Supplied: Prostate Cancer Foundation of Australia)

PCFA chief executive Anne Savage said the impacts of the cost of living were also preventing check-ups.

"In a recent survey on men's health in Australia, a very high number of respondents had opted out of essential health care because they were worried about the cost implications," Ms Savage said.

" We need to make sure that that health care is affordable for all Australians and accessible particularly for men who live in regional areas. "

Ms Savage said there were new draft guidelines in Australia for the early detection of prostate cancer.

"One of the really important changes that we are promoting right now is for interested men to get a baseline PSA test at the age of 40," she said.

"That helps us to monitor their PSA over the life course and to take action as quickly as we can if the PSA becomes elevated."

Madeline Jones is raising awareness during the Prostate Cancer Foundation of Australia's Long Run in September. (Supplied: Madeline Jones)

Since her dad's diagnosis, Ms Jones has raised nearly $100,000 for the PCFA's Long Run campaign held in September.

There will be extra meaning when she laces up her running shoes this year, with the 33-year-old aiming to raise another $52,000, to reflect her dad's age when he was diagnosed.

"My mission is to make sure other people and other families don't have to go through what my dad went through, what my brothers went through and the rest of my family have gone through," Ms Jones said.

"Dad's gone and he's not here but I still feel his presence and I know that he'll be watching me and proud of me."

title: Nationals MP takes vanilla slice support to new level with tattoo
text:
A Victorian politician has had the image of a vanilla slice permanently tattooed onto her hip.

Nationals Member for Mildura Jade Benham vowed to get the tattoo during a vanilla slice eating contest in Merbein, in Victoria's north-west.

She quipped that maybe she should get a tattoo as penance after failing to come first, and within the next few hours, she did just that.

"I immediately thought that I need to have some sort of a filter between my brain and my mouth at times, and that was one of those times," Ms Benham said.

"It was great, I don't regret it at all."

It is not the National Party politician's first tattoo, as she has several of her children's drawings inked on her.

This is, however, her first sweet treat tattoo, and she was very deliberate about its placement.

"On my hip, because vanilla slice — a moment on the lips, a lifetime on the hips," Ms Benham said.

She said the act had perhaps shocked some of her colleagues within the Victorian National Party, who were "far too sophisticated" to do such a thing themselves.

The vanilla slice tattoo on the left hip of Jade Benham. (Supplied: Jade Benham)

Walsh a clean-skin

Peter Walsh, representing the neighbouring electorate of Murray Plains, said he had never considered getting a tattoo in support of a local business or event during his political career.

"I'm not a tattoo person, so good luck to Jade on doing what she's doing to promote things, which she has done in the past," Mr Walsh said.

"I haven't got a tattoo and I'm not the muscly young person you need to be to have a tattoo.

"It's never been a consideration in my whole life."

Other Nationals politicians, including Member for Lowan Emma Kealy, Victorian Nationals leader Danny O'Brien and Federal Member for Mallee Anne Webster were asked if they would ever consider getting a tattoo, what it would be, and where they would get it.

None responded to the questions.

title: New dietary guidelines are expected in 2026. Here's what they might contain
text:
For many Australians, our first contact with official dietary guidelines was the food pyramid, which had fruit, veggies, and carbs as its base, and fats and sugar at the very top.

Over the decades, the various blocks that made up the food pyramid shifted slightly. It recently got a makeover and is now the "healthy eating plate".

Loading...

But the plate is based on guidelines published back in 2013, which are due for an update. They're currently under revision to take into account the latest nutrition research, and are expected to be published next year.

While we don't know what the new guidelines will say, we can look overseas to see what the latest dietary guidelines of other countries include.

And one issue pops up time and again: the health of the environment.

Sustainability in newer dietary guidelines

Over the past five years or so, new dietary recommendations from elsewhere around the world haven't just addressed human health — they've incorporated the health of the planet too.

Production of certain food groups, such as red meat, have a relatively higher environmental impact — on carbon emissions, land use and biodiversity loss — than others.

In 2019, a group of researchers, called the EAT-Lancet Commission, published the planetary health diet. It's designed to be adapted for different countries and cultures, and is a "plant-forward" diet, where most foods are whole grains, fruit, vegetables, nuts and legumes.

How to get the fibre you need Photo shows Smiling girl with glasses eating apple and looking at laptop. People share a lot of their lives on social media. This can even include digestion details, with content about "staying regular", bloating and fibre far from off-limits.

While red meat is not off the table, the planetary health diet suggests people eat no more than 98 grams of red meat each week.

"That's about a third of what the current Australian Guide to Healthy Eating recommends," Jessica Danaher, a RMIT University dietitian and nutrition scientist, says.

The Danish dietary guidelines, published in 2020, also emphasise climate-friendly, plant-rich eating. They suggest people eat less meat, and choose fish and legumes instead.

Other sets of dietary guidelines also explicitly incorporate environmental sustainability, but not all. Norway's guidelines, while being similar to the Danish guidelines, don't mention the environment at all (but do suggest people "eat with pleasure and make time to sit down and eat").

So will we see a focus on planetary health in the next iteration of the Australian Dietary Guidelines?

Dr Danaher suspects so: "[We may be] shifting towards looking at health from a more holistic perspective as opposed to just looking at the clinical perspective or nutritional adequacy."

What are the current Australian dietary guidelines?

You may be wondering what our current recommendations even are.

They include recommendations about breastfeeding and food safety, but mostly focus on people eating a variety of nutritious foods.

The visual representation of our guidelines is called the Australian guide to healthy eating plate, and it's divvied up into five food groups.

The five food groups include vegetables, fruit, grain, protein and dairy. (Getty Images: fcafotodigital)

What is a 'serve'? Vegetables: half a cup cooked green or orange vegetables, 1 cup raw salad vegetables, or 1 medium tomato

Fruit: 1 medium apple, two small plums, or 1 cup canned fruit (no added sugar)

Grain (cereal) food: 1 slice of bread, half a cup cooked rice, pasta or noodles, or quarter of a cup muesli

Protein: 65 grams cooked lean red meat, 2 large eggs, or 1 cup cooked or canned legumes

Dairy: 1 cup fresh milk or calcium-enriched plant-based milk, 2 slices of cheese, or three quarters of a cup yoghurt

Recommended daily minimum serves of these five food groups vary with age and sex Source: Eat For Health

It comprises around a third of grain-based foods, a third veggies and legumes, and the rest split roughly between fruit, lean protein, and dairy and dairy-alternatives.

"Discretionary foods" such as chips, chocolate, cream and soft drinks are recommended to be eaten "sometimes and in small amounts".

Despite being portrayed as a single meal, the healthy eating plate is not designed to show you what you should be eating every meal, Dr Danaher says.

" It's not so much about ticking that off every single day, but more of what it looks like, say, over the space of a few days or a week. "

For instance, the guidelines recommend no more than two serves of "discretionary foods" every day.

"One quarter of a pie at the footy is a serve of discretionary foods, so my whole pie is doubling the daily recommendations," Dr Danaher says.

"But I'm not going to eat half my pie and chuck it in the bin and go, 'Oh, I've met my pie limit for today'.

"I'll have that whole pie, but I'm not eating a pie every single day."

How many people meet the current Australian dietary guidelines?

The fruit and vegetable sections recommend people aged nine years or older eat two serves of fruit and at least five serves of vegetables every day.

According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, only 4.2 per cent of Australian adults met the recommended targets for both fruit and vegetables in 2022.

That may seem incredibly low, but the Australian dietary guidelines are just that — guidelines, Dr Danaher says.

Aussie to eat more junk by 2030, study finds Photo shows A close of a woman's mouth as she eats a donut with pink frosting, sprinkles and a rainbow-coloured lolly on it. The CSIRO says the average Australian's diet is likely to get worse within five years, hurting our health and the taxpayers' purse. So what is standing in the way of better eating?

"It's called the Australian guide to healthy eating, not the Australian rule book to healthy eating.

"It's to give us a sense of proportion, variety and moderation for a nutritional balanced approach … it gives us something to aim towards.

"Realistically, with real-world, everyday eating, people have things like travel and social events, appetite, your time, what you're able to eat between work commitments, cost, availability and even stress playing a big role."

For more on dietary guidelines, check out the full episode of Lab Notes.

title: Aus Open champion 'paralysed' by nerves in loss, as veterans bid teary farewell
text:
Australian Open champion and hometown hope Madison Keys has let a big lead slip to go down in the first round of the the US Open, losing 6-7(10/12), 7-6 (7/3), 7-5 to unheralded Mexican Renata Zarazúa.

Keys could tell she was not hitting the ball well or feeling very much at all like the confident player who claimed her first grand slam title at the Australian Open in January.

After 89 unforced errors, including 14 double faults, the sixth-seeded Keys was gone from Flushing Meadows to her 82nd-ranked opponent, despite having led by a set and 3-0.

"For the first time in a while … my nerves really got the better of me, and it kind of became a little bit paralysing," said Keys, the runner-up in New York to good friend Sloane Stephens in 2017 and a semifinalist in 2018 and 2023.

Victorious Kasatkina hopes only way is up after hectic year Photo shows Daria Kasatkina hits a forehand at the US Open. Daria Kasatkina eases into the second round of the US Open in straight sets, as she hopes to end a busy year on a high.

"I felt like I was just slow. I wasn't seeing things the way that I wanted to, which I feel like resulted in a lot of bad decisions and lazy footwork.

"For whatever reason, today I just couldn't separate myself from … feeling like winning matters just way too much."

She made so many mistakes off the spin-laden shots coming her way that Zarazúa needed to produce just eight winners to earn the biggest victory of her career.

Despite playing in the cavernous Arthur Ashe Stadium for the first time, having only had a chance to hit there once a couple of days prior, and boasting a 0-6 record against opponents ranked in the top 10, Zarazúa was unwavering.

"I'm a little bit small in height, so coming in here, it was like, 'Oh my God, this is huge,'" Zarazúa said about the largest stadium in tennis, which holds nearly 24,000 spectators.

When the match ended with Keys missing a forehand after 3 hours and 10 minutes, Zarazúa smiled as widely as possible, held her racquet atop her head, then placed a hand over her face.

She is the only Mexican left in the singles draw after Ignacio Buse was beaten by Ben Shelton in straight sets to kick off day one.

"Coming into the match I was almost crying because I was really nervous but I think the crowd made it so chill for me," Zarazúa said.

"I could hear some Mexican [fans] cheering, so that was very nice."

The emotions were also flowing elsewhere on day two, as two-time Wimbledon winner Petra Kvitova and 2022 US Open semifinalist Caroline Garcia bid farewell with opening-round losses.

Petra Kvitova returned to tennis after a terrifying home invasion in 2017. (Getty Images: Al Bello)

Kvitova, whose reached the quarterfinals in New York in 2015 and 2017, went down to France's Diane Parry 6-1, 6-0 in just 52 minutes, tearfully embracing coach and husband Jiří Vaněk before waving goodbye to Flushing Meadows.

Stream now on ABC iview Photo shows 5 women looking concerned in front of a beach with Family Next Door and iview logo. The enigmatic Isabelle arrives in the quiet seaside cul-de-sac of Pleasant Court — and suspicions quickly rise. Stream all episodes now on ABC iview.

Kvitova won Wimbledon in 2011 and 2014 and reached number two in the world, and she came back to the sport after being injured by a knife-wielding home invader in 2016.

After surgery to repair lacerations to her left hand, which she played with, she reached the Australian Open final in 2019 and a semifinal at the French Open in 2020.

The 35-year-old won 31 singles titles in her career, including 12 after the attack.

Frenchwoman Garcia was also overcome by emotion after her 6-4, 4-6, 6-3 loss to Russian Kamilla Rakhimova, but said she had no regrets about her decision.

"It means a lot, all the support. It's very special," the 31-year-old told the American crowd.

"Tennis brought me so much, some great emotions, some tough ones and it shaped me to who the person I am today.

"I grew a lot, especially in the last [few] years. I'm very at peace with my decision to say goodbye to tennis."

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AP/ABC

title: Environment department warned of rock art 'desecration'
text:
The federal environment minister was urged by his own department to intervene to protect areas of ancient rock art deemed at risk of "desecration" by industrial emissions, Federal Court documents have revealed.

The draft departmental advice was in response to an application lodged by Murujuga traditional custodian Raelene Cooper in 2022 under the Aboriginal and Torres Straight Islander Heritage Protection (ATSIHP) Act.

It centred on fears that industrial projects on the Burrup Peninsula were accelerating the degradation of ancient Indigenous rock art in the Murujuga Cultural Landscape in Western Australia's Pilbara.

The area was granted world heritage listing by UNESCO in July.

After more than three years without a response, Ms Cooper brought the matter to the Federal Court, which on Monday found the minister's department had taken an "unreasonable" length of time to respond.

Murujuga's listing includes requirements for monitoring of the impact industry has on the petroglyphs. (ABC News: Chris Lewis)

Watt's office draft recommends approval

The draft advice, tendered as an affidavit to the Federal Court and later released to the ABC, stated the minister could be "satisfied that the specified area is a significant Aboriginal area" for the purposes of section 10 of the ATSIHP Act, and that the area was "under threat of injury and desecration".

Murujuga is home to more than one million petroglyphs. (ABC News: Chris Lewis)

Section 10 allows the minister to make a declaration to preserve significant cultural heritage areas and halt works that could cause "injury or desecration".

Although the affidavit recommended the declaration, it was only for part of the area.

"The reporter concluded that the information provided supports a finding that part of the specified area is under threat of injury or desecration and recommends that you make a declaration over part of the specified area," the affidavit stated.

The draft advice is not binding, and it is up to the minister whether or not to accept it.

In a statement, spokesperson from Murray Watt's office said it was not a final decision but a "consultation step".

"A draft decision doesn't stop current industry from operating and it doesn't mean future industry will be banned," the statement said.

"We are asking all interested parties to participate in the consultation process in order to achieve the best outcome, to protect the important cultural heritage and jobs of this region."

Three-year delay 'unreasonable'

After reserving a decision last week, Justice Angus Stewart delivered his judgement on Monday, finding the delay in resolving the matter "unreasonable".

Murujuga's cultural landscape was added to UNESCO's World Heritage List in July. (ABC News: Chris Lewis)

"The delay in this case is unreasonable in the legal sense and it has not been adequately explained," he said.

But he stopped short of forcing the ministerial response Ms Cooper's lawyers had been seeking.

"It is likely there will be a decision very shortly, probably within the next few weeks," Justice Stewart said.

"For that reason, I accept there is little utility in making an order for the minister to make a declaration by that date."

Raelene Cooper fears that the outcome of her section 10 application will come too late. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

Speaking after the judgement, Ms Cooper said she was delighted with the ruling but feared it had come too late.

She said the construction of fertiliser company Perdaman's urea plant in the years since launching the section 10 had damaged significant sacred sites.

"There were three particular rock engravings … they now sit under this Perdaman site," she said.

"[Murujuga] is an environmental disaster now, there's been so much destruction at this sacred and universal site."

A government spokesperson said Mr Watt is committed to making a decision "as promptly as possible without compromising the objects of the ATSIHP Act".

title: Live: Stocks slip as Coles reveals falling profit
text:
Corporate watchdog ASIC is suing Equity Trustees Superannuation — which have $88 billion in funds under management and about 800,000 members — for its alleged role in the loss of $160 million of retirement savings in collapsed investment scheme Shield Master Fund.

Shield, a property-focused retail fund, collapsed last year leaving 5800 investors at risk of losing about $500 million in retirement savings.

ASIC has commenced civil Federal Court proceedings alleging Equity Trustees, a subsidiary of EQT Holdings Limited, a company listed on the Australian Stock Exchange.

ASIC alleges Equity Trustees failed "to exercise the same degree of care, skill and diligence as a prudent superannuation trustee would, to act in the best financial interests of its members (and) to do all things necessary to ensure the financial services covered by its Australian financial services licence were provided efficiently, honestly and fairly".

Equity Trustees oversaw the investment of around $160 million of retirement savings into Shield over 2023 and 2024.

ASIC Deputy Chair Sarah Court said ASIC was taking action against Equity Trustees as part of its ongoing work to protect members' superannuation savings.

"Instead of acting as an effective gatekeeper for its members' retirement savings, ASIC alleges Equity Trustees allowed thousands of members invest to in Shield which had no track record," she said.

"Those members ultimately saw their super balances eroded."

ASIC is seeking declarations and civil penalties from the Court.

ASIC is also still investigating Keystone Asset Management, which is the the responsible entity for Shield, and that went into liquidation.

ASIC also has on ongoing investigation into Equity Trustees in relation to the onboarding and ongoing monitoring of the First Guardian Master Fund, which has impacted thousands of more investors and left their retirement savings at risk.

For more on the collapse of the Shield and First Guardian funds, listen to this podcast:

title: Kasatkina coasts as Aussies get maiden US Open wins
text:
Daria Kasatkina has led the Australian charge through the first round of the US Open on day two, eager to end a year of upheaval on a high note.

The Russian-born world number 18 took down Romanian Elena-Gabriela Ruse 7-5, 6-1 in an hour and 18 minutes to advance to the second round in New York.

Kasatkina dropped her first two service games against her 68th-ranked opponent and was broken once more in the first set before finding her groove and closing it out.

Australian fan booted out of US Open match Photo shows Umpire James Keothavong speaks to an Australian fan in the stands at the US Open. A fan is sent out of Australian Jordan Thompson's first-round victory at the US Open, much to the delight of other members of the crowd.

The second frame was more of a procession, jumping out to a 3-0 lead and jogging through the finish line after winning her second match point.

"I'm so happy because the first match of a slam is always a tough challenge," she said.

It has been an eventful year for Kasatkina.

In March she changed allegiances from Russia, where the "international LGBT movement" was ruled an "extremist organisation", to Australia, where she got engaged to partner Natalia Zabiiako in June.

Loading Instagram content

Kasatkina cut a relieved figure on court after her win, replying "Oi, Oi, Oi" to Australian fans' "Aussie, Aussie, Aussie" call, saying she was still trying figure out how to juggle everything going on while staying focused on the court.

"I have to be honest, I could do better," she said.

"We're tennis players but we also have stuff going on outside the tennis court. There's always something going on in your life.

US Open villain rages at umpire in first-round defeat Photo shows Daniil Medvedev breaks his racquet after losing A chorus of boos and jeers has rained down on the men's 13th seed, Daniil Medvedev, at the US Open after his opponent was granted a first serve on match point.

"Most of the time if you bring it on court then you have to fight those things in your head. I've had a lot of changes in the past year, which was not easy to manage.

"I hope it's going to be a bit calmer. Now I'm quite settled and really happy about it, all my focus will go on the work and the important things.

"Sometimes there are moments when you think you are on the bottom, but the way from the bottom is only up, so this is what I'm really looking forward to."

Kasatkina next faces Russian Kamilla Rakhimova, who ended the career of France's Caroline Garcia with a first-round win, in her seventh trip to the second round at Flushing Meadows, while a couple of her new compatriots made it for the first time.

Adam Walton shocked 22nd-seeded Frenchman Ugo Humbert. (Getty Images: Al Bello)

Adam Walton scored an upset 6-4, 7-6(7/4), 5-7, 6-1 win over 22nd seed Ugo Humbert for his maiden victory in the main draw in New York.

The 85th-ranked Walton next faces Hong Kong's Coleman Wong as he tries to make it into the third round of a slam for the first time.

Qualifier Priscilla Hon also broke her US Open duck as she took down France's Leolia Jeanjean 6-3, 7-5 in 93 minutes, for her first win at a grand slam since the 2020 Australian Open.

Priscilla Hon had not won a match in the main draw of a slam since 2020. (Getty Images: Maddie Meyer)

The match was a tense affair, especially in the second set, when Hon fought off a set point at 4-5 on her own serve before rattling off three straight games to serve it out at her earliest convenience.

There was no such luck for Aleksandar Vukic, who was also shooting for his first win at Flushing Meadows.

He spent almost four hours on Court 11 against American Jenson Brooksby, who eventually came out on top 6-3, 6-7(4/7), 6-4, 3-6, 6-4.

Fellow Australian James Duckworth was also up against a local hope, with Tristan Boyer winning 6-3, 7-5, 6-4 in just over two hours, while Talia Gibson's US Open debut ended in straight sets, 6-, 6-2 against 28th seed Magdalena Frech.

title: Live: PM, Wong expected to make significant foreign affairs announcement
text:
Do you have a question for the PM? Make sure you send them through to us!

Anthony Albanese will be joining us for an interview at 5:15pm (AEST) today for an interview to answer your questions.

We want to see your questions, so send them through via the comments section above.

Passionate about the NDIS? Foreign affairs? Energy policy? Either way, let us know!
